headline: Request confirmation that someone else's registered design is valid
description: Third-party examination lets any person request IP Australia to conduct a formal examination of a registered Australian design

usageInfo.name: Disclaimer and Feedback Policy
usageInfo.text: This IP First Response website has been designed to help IP rights holders navigate IP infringement and enforcement by making it visible, accessible, and to provide information about the factors involved in pursuing different options. It does not provide legal, business or other professional advice, and none of the content should be regarded as recommending a specific course of action. We welcome any feedback via our IP First Response feedback form and by emailing us.

isPartOf.name: IP First Response
isPartOf.description: A first port of call for businesses to easily understand complex intellectual property issues.

mainEntity.name: Request confirmation that someone else's registered design is valid
mainEntity.description: Third-party examination lets any person request IP Australia to conduct a formal examination of a registered Australian design

mainEntity.name: How to proceed with Request confirmation that someone else's registered design is valid

step.name: xXx_PLACEHOLDER_xXx
step.text: Ability to pay the examination fee.

step.name: xXx_PLACEHOLDER_xXx
step.text: Consider whether to get help from an IP lawyer or IP attorney.

step.name: xXx_PLACEHOLDER_xXx
step.text: Keep copies of all correspondence and the certificate of examination.

acceptedAnswer.text:
* Offers a cost-effective challenge to a competitor’s design without starting court proceedings.
* Accessible to any person via online or postal application.
* May remove or narrow the owner’s monopoly, opening market opportunities.
* Quick administrative procedure handled online through IP Australia.

* Certification may strengthen the owner’s exclusive rights and enforcement options.
* Alerting the owner to your interest could prompt quicker or stronger enforcement action.
* Optional hearings to dispute an adverse report may incur extra fees and delays.

* The design is certified, confirming the owner’s exclusive rights.
* Note that the owner of the design may choose to make amendment to the design to address objections raised during the examination process. A list of allowable amendments can be found in the relevant section of the Designs Examiners’ Manual: [22.3. Amendments: Amending a registration | IPA Manuals](https://manuals.ipaustralia.gov.au/design/amending-a-registration).
* The registration is revoked, removing design protection.
* Parties settle the dispute commercially or by negotiation before the examination is completed - in these cases the requesting party withdraws their request for certification as part of the resolution.

[IP Australia’s fee schedule](https://www.ipaustralia.gov.au/design-rights/timeframes-and-fees#fx-tabs-0-panel-1) lists the examination fee at $500 (effective from 1 October 2024). If a third party requests examination, both parties split the fee.

mainEntity.name: How much time might be involved?

acceptedAnswer.text: IP Australia aims to issue the first examination report to the requester within 13 weeks in 85% of cases and within 16 weeks in 95% of cases. If a first adverse report is issued, the owner will then have 6 months to overcome any objections raised by the examiner. Total process duration can extend to 12 months or more if extensions of time and hearings occur. After lodging, the requester’s involvement is minimal unless the owner contests.
Any person or business, even if they are **not** the owner of the design, may request certification.

* Design right owner, who will be notified.
* IP Australia’s design examiner makes the examination decision.
* The person or business who requests the examination.
* Optional: IP lawyer or patent attorney.
